review.title: Exploiting Single-Cycle Symmetries in Continuous Constraint Problems
review.abstract: Symmetries in discrete constraint satisfaction problems have been explored and exploited in the last years, but symmetries in continuous constraint problems have not received the same attention. Here we focus on permutations of the variables consisting of one single cycle. We propose a procedure that takes advantage of these symmetries by interacting with a continuous constraint solver without interfering with it. A key concept in this procedure are the classes of symmetric boxes formed by bisecting a n-dimensional cube at the same point in all dimensions at the same time. We analyze these classes and quantify them as a function of the cube dimensionality. Moreover, we propose a simple algorithm to generate the representatives of all these classes for any number of variables at very high rates. A problem example from the chemical and#64257;eld and the cyclic n-roots problem are used to show the performance of the approach in practice.

metadata.title: Exploiting Single-Cycle Symmetries in Continuous Constraint Problems

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Since CSPs are usually solved using AI search algorithms, approaches that deal with symmetries fall into two groups: those that involve reformulating the problem or adding constraints before searching (Flener, Frisch, Hnich, Kiziltan, & Miguel, 2002; Puget, 2005), and those that break symmetries along the search (Meseguer & Torras, 2001; Gent, 2002). Variable permutations and the interchangeability of values are usually addressed by symmetries, for which a repertoire of techniques has been developed, most of which rely on compatible group theories. On the contrary, symmetries are largely ignored, despite the important growth in both theory and application.

sections.heading: 2. Symmetry in Continuous Constraint Problems
sections.text: We are interested in solving the following general continuous satisfaction problem (continuous CSP) = 1 points: Find all points x = (x1,.., xn) lying in an initial field of Rn. − − − The only peculiarity we need from a continuous constraint solver (CCS) is that it must work with an axis-aligned box in Rn as input. We also assume that the CCS solution boxes return. We say that a function s: Rn → Rn is a point symmetry of the problem if there is an associated permutation.

sections.heading: 4.1 Discussion on the Efficiency of CSYM1
sections.text: The CSym1 algorithm launches the CCS algorithm on | SRn | small boxes instead of only the original large one. Three factors affect its efficiency compared to the standard approach: 1. Fraction of the domain is processed. Only a fraction of the original domain is handled directly by the CCS. However, this fraction is a function of the periods of the SRn components. An element of the period p represents a class formed by p boxes, only one of which is processed by the CCS. Since all boxes of the original class are of the same size, the above fraction can be divided by the number of representatives by the total number of boxes in the classes.

sections.heading: 5. Two Illustrative Examples
sections.text: The two following problems were solved with the Branch-and-Prune CCS presented by Porta, Ros, Thomas, Corcho, Canto, and Perez (2008). It is a polytopic-based method similar to that used by Sherbrooke E. C. (1993) with global consistency and quadratic convergence.

sections.heading: 5.1 Cycloheptane
sections.text: If two atoms are connected by a chemical bond, it can be assumed that there is a rigid bond between them. Thus, the first approximation is that the bond lengths are constant; the second is that the angles between two successive bonds are also constant; in other words, the distances between the atoms in any subchain of three atoms are assumed to be constant; all the configurations of the atoms of the molecule that meet these distance limitations are sometimes referred to as rigid geometry hypothesis, valid conformations of the molecule in a kinematic sense; the constraints induced by rigid geometry are particularly strong when the molecular topology forms loops, as in cycloalkanes; the problem of finding all valid conformations of a molecule can be formulated as distance geometry.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusions
sections.text: We are approaching the problem of exploitation of symmetries in continuous constraints Satisfaction problems with continuous constraints solvers. Our approach is general and can use any box-oriented CCS as a black box method. The individual symmetries we have tackled are single-cylinder permutations of problem variables. The proposed strategy is to divide the domain, the n-cube initial box, simultaneously in all dimensions at the same point. This forms a series of boxes that can be grouped into box symmetry classes. A representative of each class is selected to be processed by the CCS, and all symmetries of the representatives are applied to the resulting solutions. In this way, the solutions are found within the entire initial domain while they have processed only a fraction of it - the amount of representatives of the respective class - with the CCS. The time savings achieved by processing a representative unit are achieved.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: This is an extended version of the work presented at CP 2007 (Ruiz de Angulo & Torras, 2007), where the authors acknowledge the support of the Generalitat de Catalunya within the Consolidated Robotics Group, the Spanish Ministry of Science and Education within the DPI200760858 project and the "Comunitat de Treball dels Pirineus" within the 2006ITT-10004 project.

referenceMentions.context: Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research 34 (2009) 499-520 Submitted 10/08; published 3/09

Since CSPs are usually solved using AI search algorithms, the approaches dealing with symmetries fall into two groups: those that entail reformulating the problem or adding constraints before search (Flener, Frisch, Hnich, Kiziltan, & Miguel, 2002; Puget, 2005), and those that break symmetries along the search (Meseguer & Torras, 2001; Gent, 2002).

identity) generated by this cycle by composition. Since the computational gain will be shown to be roughly proportional to n, the longest cycle appearing in the problem formulation should be chosen as input to our algorithm. This single-cycle permutation that leaves the constraints unchanged is a form of constraint symmetry in the terminology introduced by Cohen, Jeavons, Jefferson, Petrie, and Smith (2006). Note that any constraint symmetry is also a solution symmetry, but not the other way around.
The two problems below have been solved with the Branch-and-Prune CCS presented by Porta, Ros, Thomas, Corcho, Canto, and Perez (2008). It is a polytope-based method similar to that of Sherbrooke E.

The two problems below have been solved with the Branch-and-Prune CCS presented by Porta, Ros, Thomas, Corcho, Canto, and Perez (2008). It is a polytope-based method similar to that of Sherbrooke E. C. (1993) with global consistency, which exhibits quadratic convergence.

The problem of finding all valid conformations of a molecule can be formulated as a distance-geometry (Blumenthal, 1953) problem in which some distances between points (atoms) are fixed and known, and one must find the set of values of unknown (variable) distances that are compatible with the embedding of the points in R3.
of constraints consisting of equalities or inequalities of determinants formed with subsets of the fixed and variable distances (Blumenthal, 1953).
6 minutes spent when using the algorithm of Porta et al. (2008) alone, a reduction by a factor of 6.
The following polynomial equation system is the n = 5 instance of the so-called cyclic n-roots problem as described by Björck and Fröberg (1991).

metadata.abstractText: Symmetries in discrete constraint satisfaction problems have been explored and exploited in the last years, but symmetries in continuous constraint problems have not received the same attention. Here we focus on permutations of the variables consisting of one single cycle. A key concept in this procedure are the classes of symmetric boxes formed by bisecting a n-dimensional cube at the same point in all dimensions at the same time. We analyze these classes and quantify them as a function of the cube dimensionality. Moreover, we propose a simple algorithm to generate the representatives of all these classes for any number of variables at very high rates. A problem example from the chemical field and the cyclic n-roots problem are used to show the performance of the approach in practice.
